attributes.title: Stock verification
attributes.description:
• A Physical stock count was done on 02 February 2025 to determine if stock balances, i.e. raw materials and finished goods, agreed with the balances in the SAP system and to determine if stock management controls were working effectively.

  • The audit findings were as follows:

  • Bread stock had a variance of -300 Loaves out of which 224 were raised as deduction and leading to a pending variance of -76 loaves

  • Polybags had a variance of -2021 pieces

  • Yeast had a variance of +0.46 sachets

  • White Flour had a variance of +23.15kgs

  • Brown flour was +0.27Kgs.

  • Utto had a variance of +0.234
attributes.recommendation:
• Branch management is recommended to ensure proper recording of polybags damages to reduce variations noted.
  • Branch is also recommended to follow up with KAF to ensure machines are regularly maintained to reduces instances of breakdowns.
attributes.effect:
Material variances noted in in raw materials and finished goods indicate that stock controls in place are not working effectively

Significant polybags variations imply that the branch is not recording all the damaged polybags sent for approval.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Follow up With KAF for regular maintenance of Ovens 

Proper recording of Polybags damages good issue.

value:
• Polybags negative variation was caused by excess polybags damages due to excess returns for torn rubbers and the branch is operating two units. We will follow up to ensure proper recording is done
  • Bread shortfalls were caused by remixes due to Oven breakdowns.

• Polybags negative variation was caused by excess polybags damages due to excess returns for torn rubbers and the branch is operating two units, Manager is advised to maintain proper recording and submit good issue with a valid reason
  • Bread shortfalls were caused by remixes due to Oven breakdowns.
  • Manager and supervisors are advised to maintain proper recording.

In the prior audit report dated 6th November 2024 stock were as seen below:

  •  The finished product had a variance of +74 Loaves
  • Polybags had a variance of -702 Polybags
  • Yeast had a variance of -2.411 sachets
  • White Flour had a variance of -20.355kgs
  • Utto had a variance
Current

A Physical stock count was done on 02nd February 2025 to determine if stock balances, i.e. raw materials and finished goods, agreed with the balances in the SAP system and to determine if stock management controls were working effectively.
Exceptions were noted there is need to strengthen stock controls.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if stock controls in place are working effectively.

attributes.title: Crates movement
attributes.description:
A physical verification crates at the Isiolo branch was done on 3rd February 2025, to determine if the crates’ stock balances were well controlled given that the crates were loaded to customers daily.

It was noted that all the crates were accounted for, however there were significant route balances especially Mini shops as detailed below.
attributes.recommendation:
Review movement of crates in the system record versus book record and rectify the variances noted.

Minimize route crate balances as per Company policy
attributes.effect: The route balances of crates in the mini shop routes implied lapses in crate movement controls which puts the branch at risk of losing the pending crate balances in the routes.

value:
Mini shop should have constant balances -Kiambu Mini shops

We are still allocating with the trend in partnership with the sales team.

Mini shop should have constant balances -Kiambu Mini shops

We are still allocating with the trend in partnership with the sales team.

In the prior audit dated 3rd December 2025, it was noted that there was a variance between the system balance crates and the book balance record equivalent to +404 crates in book record and significant balances totalling to 183 crates.
Current
A physical verification crates at the Isiolo branch was done on 3rd February 2025, to determine if the crates’ stock balances were well controlled given that the crates were loaded to customers daily
Significant opening balances should be minimized.
Operations/Production Department
To determine of crates movement is well controlled

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
A cash balance spot check was done on 4th February 2025 to confirm if balances at hand were as per cashflow and to determine if cash controls in place are effective to reduce the risks.

 It was noted that all cash was well accounted for as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: The branch to keep up with the controls.

value: To maintain proper recordings and we will keep doing frequent spot checks
To maintain proper recordings and we will keep doing frequent spot checks

In the prior audit dated 3rd December 2024, cash balances had a negligible variance of +6 and there were two pending IOUs left un-cleared dated 20th and 26th November 2024 relating to DHO expense amount worth KES 4,200 advanced to Ramadhan that conflicted the IOU that was due.
Current
A cash balance spot check was done on 4th February 2025 to confirm if balances at hand were as per cashflow and to determine if cash controls in place are effective to reduce the risks.
Cash controls are operating effectively.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if cash controls in place are working effectively.

attributes.title: Bread weight Check
attributes.description:
Weight check for bread Produced and packed in the branch was done to ensure that the bread sent to the market met the KEBS Standard weight of 200g ,400g, 600g ,800g ,1.5 kg.

From the audit sample it was noted that there were significant underweights across all the Varieties as seen:

400 g CTW had 72%

600CTW/BT had 65%

 800 CTW had 87%

200g Minibread had 100% 

400 g S/N had 11%

400 Grande 95%

The table below is the summary of the findings.
attributes.recommendation:
Frequent spot checks on weight to ensure bread produced

and sent to the market are of correct weights.

Regular servicing of bakery machines to optimize

performance.
attributes.effect:
Violation of weights and Measures laws by supplying Underweight bread to the market exposes the company to regulatory and legal risks. This can lead to the attraction of potential penalties for non-compliance.

Underweight bread also can affect brand reputation and can lead to loss of customers.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Regular Oven maintenance

Follow up of correct prroduction procedures

value: Bread underweights were caused by Breakdown in slicing machine and faulty oven. Maintenance has been working to resolve the issue on both machines (04/02/2025)

Main cause of underweights was due to Conveyor belt of the slicer affected efficiency.

Faulty oven MBN 249 -Fimak oven (Main Oven) lower part had faulty element, bread had to overstay baking leading to loss of excess moisture.

The manager advised to push maintenance department to resolve the issue.

In the previous audit report dated 3rd December 2024, underweights were as follows:

400BT 20%

600CT 8%

800BT 4%
Current
Weight check for bread Produced and packed in the branch was done to ensure that the bread sent to the market met the KEBS Standard weight of 200g ,400g, 600g ,800g ,1.5 kg.

Proper maintenance of Ovens should be done

Correct production procedures should be strictly followed.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if Bread supplied to the market is of correct standard weight as per KEBS requirements.

attributes.title: Bread Damages analysis
attributes.description:
• A review of bread damages for a period of 27 days from 6 January 2025 to 1 February 2025 was done with the aim of determining if production and Market Damages were within the allowable threshold of 0.2% and 0.5% respectively.

  • It was noted that the production bread damages were at 0.25% of total production, which was above the set limit of 0.2% with a cost Implication of -22,161.80 while market damages were at 0.46% of total sales which was within the allowable threshold.

  • Below is a summary of the findings:

  • Production damages

     

  • Market Damages

  •
attributes.recommendation: • To schedule consistent bakery machines are Maintenance to prevent or minimize cases of breakdowns that result in production damages.
attributes.effect:
• The average production damages exceeded the KPI target by 0.05%, indicating a higher-than-desired level of waste. The cost implication suggests a loss of KES 22,161.80 due to excess damages.

  • The market damages were within the allowable threshold.
attributes.remediation_plan: Producing bread of good quality by following standard production procedures.

value:
• Market damages are within % allowable threshold.

  • Production damages have been contributed by frequent oven breakdowns.

• Market damages are within % allowable threshold.

  • Production damages have been contributed by frequent
• During the prior audit it was noted that production damages were 0.25% of the total production while market damages were 0.57% of the total sales.
Current

• A review of bread damages for a period of 27 days from 6th January 2025 to 1st February 2025 was done with the aim of determining if production and Market Damages were within the allowable threshold of 0.2% and 0.5%   respectively.
Production damages surpassed the allowable limit of 0.2%.
Operations/Production Department

To aim of this analysis was to determine if the branch correct production procedures were being followed to ensure bread of good quality was produced and therefore production and market damages are kept at allowable range of 0.2% and 0.5% respectively.

attributes.title: Production efficiency
attributes.description:
A review of production efficiency was performed to assess whether the branch utilized its production workers effectively in line with the established standards of 4.3 bags per production worker.

It was noted that production efficiency stood at 4.27 bags per production worker which was below the expected set standard of 4.3 bags per production worker. The results were as detailed below.

Table 7:Production Efficiency.
attributes.recommendation: The branch should ensure workers are hired as per productions to minimize extra costs for the company.
attributes.effect: The branch hired 7 extra workers with an extra cost of Kshs.7,606.2.
attributes.remediation_plan: Proper allocation of workers as per shift targets.

value: The Production efficiency i will  ensure 4.5 is achieved whenever everything is okey.
The Production efficiency manager is advised to ensure 4.5 is achieved whenever everything is okey.
In the previous audit report dated 3rd December, production efficiency was at 4.21 bags per production worker.
Current

A review of production efficiency was performed to assess whether the branch utilized its production workers effectively in line with the established standards of 4.3 bags per production worker.A review of production efficiency was performed to assess whether the branch utilized its production workers effectively in line with the established standards of 4.3 bags per production worker.
Production efficiency was not achieved below standard of 4.3
Operations/Production Department
To determine if human resources allocated to production were fully utilized

attributes.title: Packing efficiency
attributes.description:
Packing Efficiency for the period 6 January 2025 to 1 February 2025 was conducted with the aim of ensuring packing workers were achieving their allocated KPI of 97 Crates per packer.

It was noted that packing efficiency was at 85.16 crates which was below the standard KPI, the company hired more 648 workers with an extra cost of Kshs.72,048.

Table 8: Packing Efficiency.
attributes.recommendation: The branch should follow up with Maintenance department to ensure slicing machine maintenance is done to reduce downtimes that affects efficiency.
attributes.effect: Workers were underutilized leading to increased cost of Kshs.72,048 without a corresponding increase in productivity.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Packers allocation be done as per the prior shift loaves produced.

Slicing machine repairs ,has been repaired.

value:
• Packing Efficiency was caused by Slicing machine breakdowns, Coding machine off and on breakdowns but the issue has been resolved,

  • Packers are also slow, but we are pushing them.

  • The issue will be resolved when all the machines are in good condition. (KAF team working on it 04/02/2025)

• Packing Efficiency was caused by Slicing machine breakdowns, Coding machine off and on breakdowns but the issue has been resolved,

  • Packers are also slow, but we are pushing them.

  • The issue will be resolved when all the machines are in good condition. (KAF team working on it 04/02/2025)
The previous audit report date 3rd December 2024, packing efficiency was at 84.12 crates per packer
Current
Packing Efficiency for the period 6th January 2025 to 1st February 2025 was conducted with the aim of ensuring packing workers were achieving their allocated KPI of 97 Crates per packer.
Packers are not fully utilized.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if branch human capital resources allocated packing section was optimally utilized.

attributes.title: Mixing chart analysis
attributes.description:
An analysis of both mixing chart and mixing chart summaries was done for the period 6 January 2025 to 1 February 2025 to determine if the raw materials usage were as per the set BOM and if the set standards were achieved for production.

The analysis revealed that:

ü  Utto consumption to bags was at 100%.

ü  Average yield was 191.25 loaves per bag which was within the set standard.

ü  Average production was 161.96 bags which represented 68.05% of the target of 238 bags set.

ü  There were 5,574 cases of remixes noted for the reviewed period.

The table below illustrates the summary of the findings:

Table 9: Mixing Chart Analysis.
attributes.effect:
• Branch production capacity was underutilized, Shortfall optimization of 31.95%.

  • The high number of remixes reduces the Quality of bread and can lead to bread shortfalls.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Regular maintenance of branch oven to minimize breakdowns that causes high remixes.

working on increasing sales

value:
Production capacity is affected by the Market trend which lead to production shift cuts due to low sales and Unit 2 purpose was to produce bread to be transferred to other branches, hence it is not operating full capacity.

Frequent machine breakdowns have also affected optimization of branch production capacity.

The branch also Less employees.

High Cases of remixes was caused by frequent Oven breakdowns.

Production capacity is affected by the Market trend which lead to production shift cuts due to low sales and Unit 2 purpose was to produce bread to be transferred to other branches, hence it is not operating full capacity.

Frequent machine breakdowns have also affected optimization of branch production capacity.

The branch also Less employees.

High Cases of remixes was caused by frequent Oven breakdowns.

During the prior audit dated 3rd December 2024, the following were noted: Utto usage ratio 100 %,

Average yield 191.26

Average production 168.25 bags and 3,336 cases of remixes were noted.
Current

An analysis of both mixing chart and mixing chart summaries was done for the period 6th January 2025 to 1st February 2025 to determine if the raw materials usage were as per the set BOM and if the set standards were achieved for production.
Branch production capacity is not being fully utilized.

attributes.title: Debtors analysis
attributes.description:
A review of the debtors’ balances as of 4February 2025, was conducted to ascertain if there were instances of outstanding balances at the branch that could lead to bad debts if left unchecked.

It was noted that there were 4 blacklisted debtors, there were several customers whose debts were to be cleared from security as detailed below in Appendix 2.
attributes.recommendation: The Sales team to follow up for clearance of payments for sales done.
attributes.effect: Additional recovery costs to the company for cases of long outstanding debts that are left unchecked.
attributes.remediation_plan: Sales rep to follow up on clearance of outstanding balances.

value: New adjustment in supply we consider extra cent, security deposit and Supa point that’s why there is additional to total debts
New adjustment in supply we consider extra cent, security deposit and Supa point that’s why there is additional to total debts

During the prior audit dated 3rd December 2024 it was noted that 14 out of 29 debtors related to previous day’s sales that would be cleared the next day, 6 debtors were due for recovery from security deposit/mini shop attendant, 5 debtors arose from inconsistent customers and the remnant 4 debtors were blacklisted accounts The total outstanding debt balance was at KES 466,291 (exclusive of advance payments).
Current

A review of the debtors’ balances as of 4th February 2025, was conducted to ascertain if there were instances of outstanding balances at the branch that could lead to bad debts if left unchecked.A review of the debtors’ balances as of 4th February 2025, was conducted to ascertain if there were instances of outstanding balances at the branch that could lead to bad debts if left unchecked.
Sales rep to follow up on outstanding balances to be cleared
Operations/Production Department
To evaluate the likelihood that the amounts owed by customers will be collected.

attributes.title: Vehicles fuel consumption
attributes.description:
Vehicles fuel consumption for the period 6 January 2025 to 31 January 2025 was done to determine if fuel consumption was within the standard rates.

It was noted that fuel consumption was within the standards rates, however there were vehicles for routes Ngong, Kileleshwa and kahawa which had consumed more fuel and others had faulty mileage KCJ191X-Kahawa route, KBS234K-Embakasi route hence it was difficult to compute consumption

The summary of the audit Finding is illustrated below in Appendix 1.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should liaise with KAF to keep track of all records of fuel for shared vehicles and indicate comments in their records to reflect the same.
attributes.effect: The fuel consumption was within the standard rates; however, the few vehicles consumed more fuel but were minimal.

value:
Excess fuel consumed will be recovered from the drivers

We will follow up with KAF for faulty mileage issue to be resolved.

Excess fuel consumed will be recovered from the drivers

We will follow up with KAF for faulty mileage issue to be resolved.

In the prior audit dated 3rd December 2024, it was noted that fuel consumption in the branch was within the set standards except for 2 vehicles for Mini-shop routes that were being utilized by both the branch and head office and had missing records for fuel consumed when not in the branch.
Current
Vehicles fuel consumption for the period 6th January 2025 to 31st January 2025 was done to determine if fuel consumption was within the standard rates.
Vehicles fuel consumption was within the range
Operations/Production Department
To determine is fuel allocation to vehicles was done as per the standard rates.
